title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: Trump order aims to politicize decisions on federal science grants
items.description: Researchers worried by plan giving political appointees more control over where funding goes

items.title: Canada plans a 15% budget cut. Scientists are alarmed
items.description: Cuts could erase promised boost, researchers fear

items.title: In Guinea, the United States helped beat back malaria. Now, the disease is set to soar
items.description: Foreign aid cuts are expected to cause a rise in malaria cases and deaths across sub-Saharan Africa

items.title: Possible genetic clues to ME/chronic fatigue syndrome identified in massive study
items.description: DNA analysis of more than 15,500 people with the debilitating condition identifies eight tentative “genetic signals”

items.title: Ancient Europeans resisted inequality for 5000 years
items.description: Farming and draft animals didn’t stratify societies in Carpathian Basin

items.title: Video reveals cockatoos have 30 unique dance moves—including headbanging
items.description: Researchers now know why the caged bird dances: a form of mentally enriching play

items.title: Using electrons to make art, this scientist’s biology images grace rock albums and stamps
items.description: Steve Gschmeissner’s electron microscope image of liver cholesterol won a Wellcome Photography Prize this year

items.title: Could lithium stave off Alzheimer’s disease?
items.description: The metal is depleted in brains of people with disease and can reverse memory symptoms in mice, new study shows

items.title: Has NSF defied a court order by suspending 300 UCLA grants?
items.description: Federal judge to hear arguments relating to preliminary injunction to restore funding for other UC grants

items.title: NIH details options for limiting its payments for open-access publishing fees
items.description: Other publishing proposals would scrap reimbursements or pay peer reviewers, unprecedented steps for a major government funder
